513988241.name: Run

461500401.author: a TripAdvisor user
461500401.reviewBody: Visit metropilotano park "presa the rej\u00f3n", you can spend the weekends with your family to live together, you can also exercise as there are exercise equipment, there are play areas for children, corridors of both people and bicycles, which run through the Perimeter of the dam, enjoying its beautiful landscape. 321984883.author: a TripAdvisor user

306989163.name: Presa el Rejon Parque in Chihuahua
306989163.author: a TripAdvisor user
306989163.reviewBody:
Presa El Rejon is a city park which has been made around a large reservoir about a half mile west of the Fashion Mall. The Parque has the La Salle University on the west bank and growing Chihuahua neighborhoods around the Fashion Mall on the east and south banks. The Park was built to provide Chihuahuanese families a place to enjoy sports and the outdoors. The Park has a large 6.5 KM bike and jogging track which surrounds the lake providing great opportunities for runners, joggers and bikers to exercise in a beautiful setting. There are several exercise tracks to provide ample chances to work on strength and cardio while using the track. 

There is a great family Center situated in the southeast section of the lake adjacent to the La Salle University. Here you can find Zumba classes, children's play area, rest rooms and snack stands. There are children's play areas all around as well as exercise tracks to warm up on before taking on your next 5k run or walk. 

At Observation room, near the boat dock, you can attend scheduled yoga or spin classes or bring your telescope and setup on the roof to watch the stars at night. There are also restrooms, water and a small store for snacks here. They sell frozen popsicles here for 6 pesos and I highly recommend the chocolate flavor. There is a place to rent paddle boats or motor boats to travel on the lake for 20 to 30 pesos a half an hour for 2 to 5 people. There is also a place to rent bikes to travel on the 6.5 km track. 

 On the high hill at the family center is a huge monument to the family which can be seen for miles. Make sure to walk up the steps to the Family Monument to enjoy great views of the lake, city and wonderful sunsets. 

In the middle of the lake are two towers which provide zip line rides across the lake on the weekends.  On the east side of the lake there is a lake view amphitheater where shows and events can be put on. 

The park is fairly easy to find with routes off Av. de la Juventud near the Fashion Mall and near the intersection of Av. de la Juventud and Blvd Antonio Ortiz Mena. If coming from the hotels or fashion mall, you can take Av Politenicnico Nacional at the south end of the mall and follow it west, look for the Carl's Jr restaurant to know where to turn. Stay on the right side of Av. Politenicnico National and it will flow into Logrono Calle which will wind around the gated communities and deposit you on the side of the lake. There are places for you to park your car on the street in parking spaces facing the lake. Next you can hop over the rail and then walk down a slight hill and onto the 6.5 km track. Once at the track, turn left and head south along the track to the Family monument or right if you want to continue for 5kms around the circle. Please note that if you continue around the circle, there are not bathrooms for at least 4 to 5 kms. See the attached map.

If you are coming from the Eastside or Historic Centre of Chihuahua, I found traveling down Blvd Antonio Ortiz Mena to Av. de la Juventud to be the easiest route. Once you intersect with Av. de la Juventud, get into the frontage road as you come to the overpass and look for signs of La Salle University and Presa el Rejon. You should turn right onto Av. Prol Tecfilo Borurda and follow the avenue till it tells you to turn for La Salle University. After the turn, stay right and follow the small sign and street to Presa el Rejon entrance. The Family monument should be in front of you and you can park along the street. Normally in the afternoon there are lines of cars parked. See map attached.

This is a great time for citizens of Chihuahua and tourists as well and should be a part of any stay.

It\'s one of the few jewels of the city and It\'s a most if you\'re visiting Chihuahua for whatever purposes. This mansion is usually use for all different  arts displaying, so It depends on the part of the year you\'re paying the visit, what you\'ll find there. \nIn front of the building, there\'s a very good coffee shop called Khaldi, sit by the park in front the house with a warm coffee and enjoy the view.

In general, it is useful for knowing the city and some facts related to it.

address.streetAddress: Paseo Simon Bolivar 401, Centro, 31000 Chihuahua, CH

594079386.name: Quinta Gameros
594079386.author: a TripAdvisor user
594079386.reviewBody: Such a beautiful place! So much art in one place. You get to walk into each of the rooms and read a little about the objects and their significance.\n

address.streetAddress: Paseo Simon Bolivar 401, Centro, 31000 Chihuahua, CH

592257963.name: Need to visit ASAP
592257963.author: a TripAdvisor user
592257963.reviewBody: This place is just amazing, beautiful old house, you can really appreciate history in here. If you go to Chihuahua, need to visit.

address.streetAddress: Paseo Simon Bolivar 401, Centro, 31000 Chihuahua, CH

588664828.name: Beautiful 19th century house
588664828.author: a TripAdvisor user
588664828.reviewBody: This 19th century home is ornately decorated and richly furnished. It was one of my favorite places in Chihuahua. It is definitely worth a visit!

address.streetAddress: Paseo Simon Bolivar 401, Centro, 31000 Chihuahua, CH

575172483.name: Very Impressive
575172483.author: a TripAdvisor user
575172483.reviewBody:
The grand 2nd empire huge house is impressive with all its ornamentation.
Inside is the most ornate art noveau furniture I have seen - some of it really over the top. 
Not all rooms are furnished, but the ones that are, are amazing. 
This is a facility that is still used so doesn’t have a landscaped yard but facade and interior are worth the visit.

address.streetAddress: Paseo Simon Bolivar 401, Centro, 31000 Chihuahua, CH

566586278.name: My Mexican maternal roots are from this northern state of Chihuahua..
566586278.author: a TripAdvisor user
566586278.reviewBody:
As my great great grandmother was born in Parral and took the family to the border city of Ciudad Juarez, but that is another story. I walked here from another museum.  A lot of local places to eat on the way. The house itself will mesmerize you upon seeing it from the outside! It is a restored and lighter version of the 60s tv show The Munsters with Ed Guinn. I had visited before but it was before I started writing for Trip Advisor. Upon entering and paying the small fee, I requested to leave my shopping bag at the front. I really do NOt know if there is a guided tour or not. This is one of a few museums to offer bilingual descriptions of the rooms for those few English speaking tourists. One of the workers here told me the last person to live here was a woman named Eliza, but she had to vacate the house because she could not afford it and somehow it ended up in the university's hands

This house is a must for Mexican history buffs like myself who like old architecture, furniture, and more! You can view the unique work that artisans used to create on the high ceilings, walls, and really all over this house. Just describing each room would be like writing a book. As I viewed each room, I imagined how life was like at the turn of the century. There was a room with artwork displayed but I really did not pay too much attention to it. After I viewed the house, another worker told me that there is a small café in the backyard. I was going to go outside anyway. I was amused by the animals that the gardener created on the bushes especially the koala!

The personnel at the museum café was very friendly. At this time, I really wanted tea and not coffee. Omar told me that he just had green tea, but I said that it was fine. The tea was brewed from leaves and NOt a bag. There were other little snacks available for your sweet tooth. I also saw some cups and t shirts for sale but my bag was heavy enough already. When I left, I meant to ask to see if I could see the basement, but there were some other visitors asking questions; I was also tired and totally forgot to ask. So I guess I will leave it until next time

address.streetAddress: Paseo Simon Bolivar 401, Centro, 31000 Chihuahua, CH

555979003.name: The love lost Taj Majal of Chihuahua
555979003.author: a TripAdvisor user
555979003.reviewBody:
Very interesting museum, now run by the University of Chihuahua, as a cultural center. The interior style is very much in the Baroque Style. 

Mr Gameros, original owner built the mansion in 1907 for his wife. Unfortunately, his wife fell in love with the Architect and fled shortly before the Mexican Revolution of 1910. Mr. Gameros, with heavy heart of his love lost decided never occupied the Mansion and with the revolution in full swing fled to El Paso, Texas. 

Each room is nicely presented with elaborate broquet furnishings and wall tapestries. 

Worth a visit...last about 1-2 hours.

address.streetAddress: Paseo Simon Bolivar 401, Centro, 31000 Chihuahua, CH

538168230.name: Nice old house, long history
538168230.author: a TripAdvisor user
538168230.reviewBody: We visited and joined a guided tour I this house. The interior design is amazing and worth watching, attention to detail and integration with nature. The art exhibited left something to the imagination, and my overall impression was that the students whose art was exhibited should enjoy more sex so that their art could focus on other themes. Then, again, that could well be said of many modern art museums around the world.

address.streetAddress: Paseo Simon Bolivar 401, Centro, 31000 Chihuahua, CH

535691517.name: Love this place!
535691517.author: a TripAdvisor user
535691517.reviewBody: This is a beautiful place to come and learn about chihuahua and their culture, they are always art shows and conferences and things to learn about. \n\nBeautiful vintage house for all edges:)

address.streetAddress: Paseo Simon Bolivar 401, Centro, 31000 Chihuahua, CH

525842167.name: Beautiful is Not Enough
525842167.author: a TripAdvisor user

address.streetAddress: Paseo Simon Bolivar 401, Centro, 31000 Chihuahua, CH

address.streetAddress: Paseo Simon Bolivar 401, Centro, 31000 Chihuahua, CH

address.streetAddress: Paseo Simon Bolivar 401, Centro, 31000 Chihuahua, CH

479788817.name: Nice mansion

366475631.name: Another must stop in central Chihuahua
366475631.author: a TripAdvisor user
366475631.reviewBody:
This house was built buy one of the wealthiest man in Chihuahua early last century as a wedding gift for his young bride to be. The house wast built in a record 2 years period with furniture, wood and construction material imported from Europe and brought to location on a 2 month journey over the rough terrain and road form the time. 
The luxury and details of this palace are breathtaking, taking into consideration the remoteness of this city in the early 1900's.

The owner of the house never got married or inhabited the house since it was expropriated by Pancho Villa during the Mexican Revolution along with all the houses in  the neighbourhood. ( He fled to the US and died to years later)

The house is french baroque style with some art novou, specially in the interiors.

You will be amazed at the impressive furniture right out of a French castle. 

The curator always is keen to share his knowledge about the art work in the house. 

This is a must stop in Chihuahua.

address.streetAddress: Paseo Simon Bolivar 401, Centro, 31000 Chihuahua, CH

354126636.name: European style with a Mexican twist.
354126636.author: a TripAdvisor user
354126636.reviewBody: We visited here with 2 Mexican friends. They were ecstatic, never seen anything like it before. But if you come from Europe none of this will come as much of a surprise. It is all Belle Epoque/Arte Nouveau albeit with a Mexican twist. The furniture is made in Mexico and is a bit odd. For example, the \'English\' music room has furniture encrusted with jewels. Not something you would see in England.\nBut the oddest thing is the child\'s bedroom decked out with scenes from little red riding hood. Guaranteed to give any child nightmares if you ask me.

298971276.name: Quinta Gameros
298971276.author: a TripAdvisor user
298971276.reviewBody: The house is done in the French Art Nouveau Style, and is beautiful National Treasure which was built by Manuel Gameros Ronquillo for his young wife. Construction started in October 1907 and finished in November 1910, just as the Mexican Revolution was commencing. Sadly Gameros\' wife died during construction and his family fled to the United States in 1913 to avoid the Revolution. Afterwards, Francisco Villa used the house as an office and later Venustiano Carranza used the house as his personal residence during the Mexican Revolution. It is now owned by the local University, which uses it for Art Exhibitions and Public Viewings. \n\nIt costs 26 pesos for Adults to enter and it is while worth it.

The art nouveau movement may have been a short-lived one, but the architecture and domestic arts that make up this building are a living testament to it. Simply gorgeous.

238895067.name: Cool Achitectural Gem
238895067.author: a TripAdvisor user
238895067.reviewBody: This beautiful Art Nouveau building houses a collection of furniture designed by Mexican lawyer Jose Luis Requena, as well as permanent art exhibitions.\nBuilt by a silver baron for his daughters wedding but never lived in.  A real architectural gem, it fell into disrepair, all the furnishing stolen.  Fortunately the University of Chihuahua purchased it, restored the interior and with a donation of period furniture, the place is once again gorgeous inside and out.  The university uses it fir special occasions and when not in use its open to the public with no admission charge on Sundays.  $26 Pesos Mon-Sat.  It is worth a visit.

484957817.name: Nice
484957817.author: a TripAdvisor user
484957817.reviewBody:
Beautiful piece of history at downtown area.
"Catedral" name for the main church in Chihuahua city, old colonial Spanish construction like a cross ,  very roomy and higher ceilings with stone sculptures. Big bells sound every morning, midday, and evening, it's like a magic moment. 
Inside decoration of colonial age according the traditional roman catholic religion . 
There's a tale of a sculpture of a Christ which start turning black in response a some miracles .
Got two atriums altars , the original made it from rock by hand and the actual made it of marble form Italy 
Misterious place by side underground , become a museum of sacred art, which in old times was connected by tunnel with other church 2 miles away . 
Get some extra cash ( not much) for people asking for help outside . 
Hotels and restaurants around at good prices. 
Live music weekends

458887729.reviewBody: I have been comping to this centro since I was born as my parents are from Chihuahua. This centro has seen many changes over the last few decades.  I saw my first movie here, bought my first pair of cowboy boots here and remember running up and down the streets.  The centro has had major improvements over the years.  It is becoming a more modern shopping center.  The streets are closed offering a perfect spot for a Sunday stroll and a paleta Michoacana.  There are more Tarahumara indians than before as they have come down from the siera to sell their goods.  The cathedral is a beautiful place located in the central park.  It is Spanish Baroque.  There is a historic pavilion there that I used to play in, which offers weekend music by local musicians.  This is a very family friendly spot and very safe.

299036930.name: Chihuahua\'s Downtown Historic District
299036930.author: a TripAdvisor user
299036930.reviewBody:
The downtown historical district has many of the museums, plazas and cathedrals. The district starts with the San Francisco de Asis Cathedral and two Plazas, the Grand plaza of Chihuahua and the Plaza of the Angel. Just below these Plazas are the Casa Chihuahua and Palace of the Governor. Within the Palace of the Governor is also the Museum of Hidalgo and the Museum of Arms. Casa Chihuahua also houses the Dungeon where Miguel Hidalgo y Costilla spent his last days. 

The Historic District follows along two walkable streets which are closed to car traffic. They are the Avenues Libertad (Liberty) and Victoria (Victory). These Avenues are lined with many restaurants, stores and hotels. At the end of the district is the Catedral de Chihuahua and its beautiful Plaza. 

If you are time bound or would like a great over view of the area I would greatly recommend taking the Chihuahua Barbaro - Day tours. The Spanish tour is 150 pesos and the English tour is 250 pesos and requires at least 4 persons. The company also offers tours guided by historical Living history figures like Pancho Villa.  Look for Lalya in the Tour booth between Casa Chihuahua and the Governor's Palace to help you find the best tour

You should plan to stay at least a day or two in the historical district as there is so much in the area to see and do.

312900295.name: Museo Semilla - An Awesome Children\'s Museum in downtown Chihuahua
312900295.author: a TripAdvisor user
312900295.reviewBody:
Museo Semilla was once the city of Chihuahua's central Trucking center, downtown. Then in 1999 the State of Chihuahua's DIF (Integral Family Development System) took over the site and created a wonderful Children's Museum. Because of the buildings shape, which is similar to a seed, the building was called Museo Semilla or in English, the Seed Museum. This facility's true purpose is to plant the seed of science, knowledge and information in the minds of children in hopes that they will make it their own and let the knowledge grow. 

The museum is split in two different sections, with Space and Natural History on one side and Science, Geography and Geology on the other. Here in the Miami area of Florida, we are blessed with two really great children's museums. I must admit that Museo Semilla is on par with these American museums and is many ways it's interaction is better. 

The Museum starts with a dizzying trip to the moon across a bridge with a revolving circular mirror and light show used to create a feeling of flying through space. Next is a model of the lunar surface, complete with a walking space man, which was quite well done, and almost like a Capricorn One mockup. There are wonderful NASA models of Apollo 11 and the space shuttle as well as a mock up of a module from the international space station. In the space station mock up, kids can move the giant robotic arm or practice sleeping while standing up in a harness like astronauts. All the while, a drifting Apollo Astronaut looks on them from the ceiling above. 

In the Dinosaur section, kids are shown fossils from Dinosaurs found in the Chihuahua area. There is also a bone yard where future scientists can seek their own Dinosaur finds. There is a working farm, where the children can milk cows, watch chickens laying eggs and pet a horse.

In the natural Earth Section, there is a working model of the Planet Earth, which allow children to slide through it's crust and peer into the Earth's core. There is a cave the kids can walk through complete with bats and dinosaur fossils on the walls. There is a working volcano, which allows children to be inside the cone while the volcano erupts with full sound and visual lava flowing. In a working model of Plate tectonics, children can walk across a visual map of the world's seven major plates which move when stepped on.  

In the next area, we get to real science with exhibits which feature Newton's theory of gravity, a working Van Der Graaff's generator, which make your hair stand on end; a working Tesla Coil, which powers lights as it runs; a working bed of nails the children can lay on; and an great working model of pulley systems similar to those found in modern elevators. If that was not enough to get you excited, there is a working gyroscope which the kids can ride and if your not careful lose their lunch at the same time. There is so much hands on science that you cannot help but be impressed and the children cannot help but learn. 

It took us about 2 and half hours to go through the whole museum and I must say that it was really great fun. 

Admission will cost you 40 pesos or about $2.75 US for adults and 35 pesos or about $2.10 US for children and seniors. The cost is well worth the investment as the kids will be thoroughly entertained. 

The museum is open Tuesday through Friday from 9:00am till 5:00pm and Saturday to Sunday from 11:00am till 6:00pm.

address.streetAddress: Calle Progreso #1201 Col. Centro

659766057.name: Definitely worth a visit!
659766057.author: a TripAdvisor user
659766057.reviewBody: We had an enjoyable visit to this museum.....the building itself is beautiful and there were an interesting variety of exhibits as well as a musician playing live music :)  Very reasonable fee for us old folk @ only half price of 25 pesos per person and a 10 peso fee to take photos...excellent value!

656880150.name: Great museum with English translations on most exhibits
656880150.author: a TripAdvisor user
656880150.reviewBody: $3 (usd) was the cost to visit this very friendly and interesting museum. They had several exhibits covering the history, geography, and architectural past in the museum. I spent a good two hours walking around and could have spent much more. I highly recommend this museum to anyone visiting Chihuahua who wants to learn more about this beautiful state.

639920213.name: Very nice museum
639920213.author: a TripAdvisor user
639920213.reviewBody: Excellent representative display of climate zones. Signage in English.. well maintained. Very nice guards to explain topics.

578410907.name: Thoroughly enjoyable
578410907.author: a TripAdvisor user
578410907.reviewBody:
The tour started with downstairs temporary exhibit of a marvelous abstract painter with the most glorious colors. We enjoyed the work so much, we returned a 2nd time.
Upstairs are some great pictures of different terrains of Chihuahua state and other types of displays as: 
Theatrical people from Chih., brief history of Mormons here, sculptures of Anthony Quinn, early and Mata Ortiz pottery just to name a few.
The building is beautiful, full of light and has some good look out points. It is a manageable size so does not take too long.

566832406.name: In the historical part of downtown Chihuahua
566832406.author: a TripAdvisor user
566832406.reviewBody: I will stop here every time, I visit my maternal state capital. I thoroughly enjoy it every time because it is my history! This time I saw a lot of students on field trips. I almost feel like it is my obligation 2 join them since I remember escorting my students on these kind of excursions. This museum is a great way to learn about my state and people which are the Menonites who immigrated here for religious reasons from Germany, the Tarahuamara Indians who have been here for centuries, and the normal working person like myself! Also the desert and the different environments. Allow yourself plenty of time to learn about my maternal state  of Chihuahua. There is a little coffee shop and bookstore on the first floor and you are required to leave your bag or backpack in front!

561339320.name: Nice museum!
561339320.author: a TripAdvisor user
561339320.reviewBody: Great museum in the heart of the historic center.  Beautiful building, with some really good exhibits that illustrate the history and diversity of the State of Chihuahua.  Definitely should make an effort to visit if you are in town.

521858218.name: Hidalgos Jail in Chihuahua
521858218.author: a TripAdvisor user
521858218.reviewBody: A very interesting place to visit and acknowledge part of the history of M\u00e9xico in Chihuahua. Excellent tourist guides, kind and friendly.

502993240.name: Very informative and a great representation of the state of Chihuahua
502993240.author: a TripAdvisor user
502993240.reviewBody: Our family LOVED this museum.  We had wished we would have visited this before we went to the Copper Canyon area. It would have giving us a better insight to the area and the people.  I highly recommend visiting this beautiful gem!!

498609928.name: Worth a trip.  Interesting...but not amazing
498609928.author: a TripAdvisor user
498609928.reviewBody: On Sundays it is free.  They are closed on Mondays. Nice museum, lots of history and git to learn alot about Chihuahua.  I took my kids in strollers.

485132352.name: Great little museum
485132352.author: a TripAdvisor user
485132352.reviewBody: An absolutely great little museum that you just can\'t miss when in Chihuahua. A must when in town, just be careful with the photo restrictions. It\'s military property and there are certain rules with regards to where you can take photographs.

473706135.name: Mexico history alive here
473706135.author: a TripAdvisor user
473706135.reviewBody: This museum has been modernized inside and has terrific permanent and short-term exhibits. The cell in which Father Hidalgo was held has a dramatic movie of his last days cast up on the wall as you stand in front of the actual cell. Very moving.

467601135.name: History of Chihuahua
467601135.author: a TripAdvisor user
467601135.reviewBody: I was part of a tour given by the curator.  It was fantastic. It included a wonderful overview of the history of the city and state of Chihuahua. This included a very interesting display of some of the mineral riches found in Chihuahua.  We also visited the cell where Hidalgo was kept before his execution. And we learned how the structure had changed during its history.  There was also a very interesting art exhibit on display.  The structure itself is quite impressive, with a very substantial atrium.

465949058.name: Concerts, Expositions
465949058.author: a TripAdvisor user
465949058.reviewBody: Casa Chihuahua use to present free cultural performances with very good level, there are also expositions from different topics which are very interesting.

461301291.name: My visit to museum Casa Chihuahua.
461301291.author: a TripAdvisor user
461301291.reviewBody: if you want to visit Chihuahua I invite to you to visit the museum Casa Chihuahua, is divided mainly into three areas: site museum, temporary exhibit area and the most important for mi is that is state heritage museum intended to inform visitors about the attractions of the State of Chihuahua.\n\nThis is in the center of the city and you can see other important places around of the museum like  Palacio de Gobierno and Plaza del Angel. Its so beutiful and you can disfruit of diferent food in Plaza Libertad.

443775143.name: A real gem
443775143.author: a TripAdvisor user
443775143.reviewBody: If you\'re travelling and have a couple of hours you need to make a stop here if you want a greater understanding of the state of Chihuahua. Especially to see the actual cell where Dolores Hidalgo was kept before his execution. I\'m from California but have lived in this city and worked in this musuem many years ago with my husband on a Tarahumara art and identity workshop he created for Tarahumara kids living in the city called "kolimi" (rainbow). I recently visited again now with my 4yo and 18mo old and it was interesting and enjoyable.

396886476.name: A great place to visit in Chihuahua
396886476.author: a TripAdvisor user
396886476.reviewBody: The museum is wonderful, with a visual and tactil description of the different landscapes of the state, paintings, theater and music on Thursdays evenings and an historical dungeon where the father of Mexico has been in jail.\nFree on Sundays. Don\'t leave without seeing it.

382843776.name: beautifull building
382843776.author: a TripAdvisor user
382843776.reviewBody: It is totally worthwhile to visit this amazing building. It has a very nice permanent exposition, and the itinerary ones are very good. Right now it holds an exposition by world known artist Agueda Lozano , a local painter who lives in Paris and is a great artist

358838862.name: Interesting and Informative
358838862.author: a TripAdvisor user
358838862.reviewBody: This museum is housed in a beautiful building with really friendly staff.  It is worth a visit with interactive and informative displays about Chihuahuas history  and ecosystems.  All the signage was in both English and Spainish, however, the lighting made the signs difficult to read at times.  We mainly went to see Hildago\'s dungeon cell which was pretty sanitized and disappointing.

353934368.name: Nothing much to see here
353934368.author: a TripAdvisor user
353934368.reviewBody: Firstly it costs 50 pesos (5 times the cost of the Pancho Villa museum - which is much better). And then there is not much to see of interest. Some rather child friendly displays.\nThe photo\'s above are misleading; the car with bullet holes belonged to Panch Villa and is not in this museum.\nSave your valuable pesos for a jugo narancha!

346255556.name: Take plenty of time, as it offers a lot.
346255556.author: a TripAdvisor user
346255556.reviewBody: Great place, formerly a government palace, then the postal office, now a Museum of the history of the people and the state of Chihuahua.  Take plenty of time to make the visit worthwhile.  The staff is very friendly.   The information is provided both in english as well as in spanish.

298881057.name: Visit Casa Chihuahua
298881057.author: a TripAdvisor user
298881057.reviewBody: This is a great museum which covers the cultural, history and background of the State of Chihuahua. It is a great place to go to better understand City and State. Try to go on a Sunday because it is free to public. In the basement is the prison cell where Miguel Hidalgo y Costilla was held prisoner. There is also a good exhibit about the money from the days when the building served as a Mint. \n\nThere is an additional 10 peso charge if you wish to use your camera during the visit

293903928.name: Nice museum
293903928.author: a TripAdvisor user
293903928.reviewBody: Great museum, divided in two main areas, one that explains all about the region and the second explains about the Mexican Insurgent\u2019s and the time of living.

282250644.name: What a Surprise This Place Was!
282250644.author: a TripAdvisor user
282250644.reviewBody: Well curated, with labeling in Spanish and English, I was impressed from start to finish. The video rooms with Chihuahua\'s terrain and Eco-systems were a modern touch along with the interactive displays in many of the galleries. I highly recommend it.

244331610.name: A very good regional museum
244331610.author: a TripAdvisor user
244331610.reviewBody: This is the state\'s official museum.  It covers history, geography and nature and includes the cell where Miguel Hidalgo was kept prior to his execution.  It is a modern museum and well worth 90 minutes of your time.

233362729.name: Museo Casa Chihuahua
233362729.author: a TripAdvisor user
233362729.reviewBody: A nice collection of pottery from the pre hispanic ruins in Chihuahua such as Casas Grandes, Paquime Archaeological site.

229326873.name: Interesting overview of Chihuahua
229326873.author: a TripAdvisor user
229326873.reviewBody: Take three hours to check on limited archaological collections on the Second floor, and the Miguel Hidalgo prison cell, where he was held almost a year before his fusiladle. Hidalgo is one of the Founding Fathers after Indepedence from Spain (1810-1821). The Neoclassical building was built to host Porfirian (dicatorship) public offices by late 19th Century -- preservations is very good.\nIn the lower level also see armory used by Pancho Villa and revolutionaries (1910-1917).

201485196.name: A MOST TO VISIT IN CHIHUAHUA
201485196.author: a TripAdvisor user
201485196.reviewBody:
While in Chihuahua City, make sure You visit Casa Chihuahua museum  a permanent exibit is the dungeon of Father Miguel Hidalgo, Father of the Mexican Independence as He was kept as a prisioner here from april 23rd to July 30th 1811.

after visiting Casa Chihuahua make sure You walk into the state capitol building to continue with the Independence history as here is the Altar dedicated in 1956 to Father Hidalgo as the place where He was executed the morning of july 30th, 1811.

Also Have a local tour guide explain to You the Murals of Aaron Piña Mora and learn about the History of the state of Chihuahua.

165890094.name: Interesting museum in downtown
165890094.author: a TripAdvisor user
165890094.reviewBody: Downtown Chihuahua is a beautiful place and very appealing to visit because despite the intense activity of offices and local businesses in the area it\'s calm and enjoyable to walk around visiting beautiful buildings such as the Museo Casa Chihuahua. Not to be missed is the cell where Miguel Hidalgo, the hero of Mexico\'s independence, was kept before being shot in Palacio de Gobierno (the place can also be visited across from the museum and the building is very beautiful too).\nCasa Chihuahua has also some very interesting displays from Mexico\'s and Chihuahua\'s history.

141424264.name: Many excellent museums in Chihuahua!
141424264.author: a TripAdvisor user
141424264.reviewBody: Most visitors from north of the border bypass Chihuahua when visiting the Copper Canyon but that is a mistake. This is a vibrant city with several exceptional museums, of which Casa Chihuahua with its displays on local history and culture is one. Note that the Governor\'s Palace just across the street in not only also well worth a visit -- it is full of extraordinary murals and gives out a very well-written guide to them in English -- but also includes an extremely helpful tourist information office with English-speaking staff.

577152609.name: Uplifting with lights and Nativity Scene
577152609.author: a TripAdvisor user
577152609.reviewBody: We visited Chihuahua and the Plaza de Armas where this church was situated.  It was approaching Christmas time so the workers were busy putting up Christmas lights and decorations all along the walking streets and the plaza.  They had also built a nativity scene in one of the plaza corners. They were also setting up a Santa Claus place

address.streetAddress: Plaza de Armas

545820219.name: The Heart of Chihuahua
545820219.author: a TripAdvisor user
545820219.reviewBody: A must see on any tour of downtown Chihuahua. Both the interior and exterior of this basilica are photogenic.

address.streetAddress: Plaza de Armas

525843791.name: Gorgeous Beauty in Pedestrian Area of City
525843791.author: a TripAdvisor user
525843791.reviewBody: As beautiful as some small cathedrals in Europe.  Make sure to not only go into the main church, but check out the side chapel where there is more gold ornate trim.  We visited as the city was getting ready for 16 de septiembre celebrations so much activity around it in the pedestrian city center area.

address.streetAddress: Plaza de Armas

364607411.name: Beautiful church
364607411.author: a TripAdvisor user
364607411.reviewBody: Built in the late 1700\'s, open to public most churches are closed until Sunday. Religious alters are very depicted in old  style. Worth a stop for prayer and a pic or two.

address.streetAddress: Plaza de Armas

326636312.name: Wonderful History
326636312.author: a TripAdvisor user
326636312.reviewBody: Best to go with a guide, he will fill you in on all the history of the Basilica. It is very well done

address.streetAddress: Plaza de Armas

299266842.name: La Catedral de Chihuahua
299266842.author: a TripAdvisor user
299266842.reviewBody:
The Cathedral was started in 1734 by the architect José de la Cruz, but it was not finished until the end of the War for Mexican Independence in 1826. It is a beautiful structure with a wonderful Plaza just in front of City Hall. It is lit nicely at night and the Plaza is a great place to walk about during the day or you can just sit and feed the pigeons. 

In the middle of the Plaza, directly in front of the Cathedral is a great statue to Álvar Núñez Cabeza de Vaca the Spanish Explorer who discovered the area for Spain.

There is great access to the North-South Vivabus line by taking the Catedral Station entrance at either side of the front of the Cathedral. The bus station is down the two flights of stairs.

address.streetAddress: Plaza de Armas

244331666.name: A beautiful baroque cathedral
244331666.author: a TripAdvisor user
244331666.reviewBody: This is a beautiful 19th-century church located in the city\'s central plaza.  See it at night for a stunning scene.

address.streetAddress: Plaza de Armas

232331745.name: Very lovely!
232331745.author: a TripAdvisor user
232331745.reviewBody: Another very beautiful church with some actually nice artworks. As are most in Mexico, it is well worth a visit.

address.streetAddress: Plaza de Armas

229327935.name: Barroque of the North
229327935.author: a TripAdvisor user
229327935.reviewBody: Pretty chuch on the outside. The indoors are simple. Around the church you can see some excavations of old pavement and a small religious art museum.\nThe facade is beatiful and there is a lively, charm plaza in front.

address.streetAddress: Plaza de Armas

228542956.name: Beautiful Cathedral!
228542956.author: a TripAdvisor user
228542956.reviewBody: I was here for a service and this is one of the places that was maintained when Chihuahua got all large streets, the place is quiet, and you can see all the architecture and paintings and saints inside.  If you like to see some historic places this one you cannot miss!\nHope you enjoy...

address.streetAddress: Plaza de Armas

198572500.name: Impressive Exterior
198572500.author: a TripAdvisor user
198572500.reviewBody: Impressive exterior, but the interior is very simple.  I would have expected more for a capital city, but worth a visit, nonetheless.

address.streetAddress: Plaza de Armas

165888287.name: Beautiful church
165888287.author: a TripAdvisor user
165888287.reviewBody: The Basilica is a very beautiful church in the center of downtown Chihuahua. It can be visited in just a few minutes but it\'s worth it and the downtown area around it is really nice despite it being a center of offices and local business. It\'s surprising how calm the area is despite all the activity, it\'s very enjoyable to walk around downtown visiting beautiful buildings like the Basilica.

address.streetAddress: Plaza de Armas

163010518.name: Colonial architecture
163010518.author: a TripAdvisor user
163010518.reviewBody: This Cathedral is an old, old building constructed in the 1725. I had not seen this church in 19 years so I made it a point to go see the inside of the church as it is beautiful to look at. There are always people inside at any time. Don\'t miss it if you are traveling to Chihuahua!

address.streetAddress: Plaza de Armas

143830377.name: Not impressive at all.  Nice facade though
143830377.author: a TripAdvisor user
143830377.reviewBody: It was not as I expected being the cathedral od the capital of Chihuahua.  A lot of constructions arround

address.streetAddress: Plaza de Armas

621493062.name: Central square with everything
621493062.author: a TripAdvisor user
621493062.reviewBody: Catedray and Alcaldia office in colonial architecture, shops, traditional food and pretty walk walking for a couple of hours until a whole day.

address.streetAddress: Calle segunda, s/n

588489744.name: Bonito, remodelado.
588489744.author: a TripAdvisor user
588489744.reviewBody: A remodeling was done of the square.  It is gorgeous, perfect to spend some time walking around, having a coffee or visiting small shops.

address.streetAddress: Calle segunda, s/n

541453347.name: Great place, full of life
541453347.author: a TripAdvisor user
541453347.reviewBody: This square truly is the beating heart of Chihuahua. We had a great time hanging out there. We saw people dancing, kids playing, couples relaxing, and so on. All kinds of shows fight for attention which gets a bit hectic but still entertains.

address.streetAddress: Calle segunda, s/n

676366905.name: Hermoso
676366905.author: a TripAdvisor user
676366905.reviewBody: Un lugar excelente para estar en contacto con la naturaleza es una cosa impresionante con muchos lugares para ver es muy recomendable ir

650889686.name: S\u00faper lindo
650889686.author: a TripAdvisor user
650889686.reviewBody: Un paseo cercano a la ciudad que vale la pena. No hay casetas y la entrada es de 40 pesos por veh\u00edculo. Nos dimos cuenta que la mejor temporada para visitarlo no es la de lluvias ya que de la entrada al sitio. a la cueva principal, atraviesa varias veces el r\u00edo. Si no ha llovido esto no es un problema.

639190870.name: Hermoso y misterioso
639190870.author: a TripAdvisor user
639190870.reviewBody: Simplemente extraordinario, un lugar que vale la pena conocer. En lo personal me impresiona como pudieron crearse esas formaciones rocosas en un terreno practicamente plano... Ademas muy esta cerca de la ciudad de Chihuahua. \nVale la pena darse una vuelta por ah\u00ed. Ademas cada noviembre se realiza una carrera que sale del ca\u00f1on de Nam\u00farachi y termina en el pueblo de San Francisco de Borja, sin duda una gran experiencia.\n

636182751.name: Bonito lugar
636182751.author: a TripAdvisor user
636182751.reviewBody: Es un lugar muy agradable para conocer y tener actividad al aire libre con la familia. Al parque le falta organizaci\u00f3n e infrastructura (no hay ba\u00f1os por ejemplo) y el estacionamiento esta a la "ah\u00ed no m\u00e1s".  Pero si vale la pena ir.

627080378.name: Muy hermoso
627080378.author: a TripAdvisor user
627080378.reviewBody: Yo andaba en la comunidad menonitas y no se me hizo nada cerca llegar a Namurachi. Es un lugar para ir temprano y grupos grandes. Hay que tener paciencia para llegar.

619156251.name: Impresionante lugar, solo eso
619156251.author: a TripAdvisor user
619156251.reviewBody: Un viaje corto de la capital del estado Chihuahua, una formaci\u00f3n rocosa interesante que deja buen sabor de boca, lo malo es que no hay nada m\u00e1s que ver u observar. incluso las propuestas gastronomicas se limitan a un improvisado restaurant y la tiendita del pueblo para comer papitas o pastelitos comerciales.

618509418.name: sesion de fotos
618509418.author: a TripAdvisor user
618509418.reviewBody: Excelente opci\u00f3n para ir de campo y pasar el rato con la familia, amigos o en este caso una sesi\u00f3n de fotos al aire libre y diferente. me encant\u00f3 el lugar, esta cerca de la ciudad, bello lugar muy recomendado.

612636280.name: Expedici\u00f3n tranquila, ideal para d\u00eda de campo.
612636280.author: a TripAdvisor user
612636280.reviewBody:
Es un lugar ideal para personas que quieren adentrarse en la naturaleza y no cuenten con tanta condición. Para llegar al cañón hay que cruzar un río en auto, es algo muy padre, y además hay un puente colgante muy divertido.

Al fondo hay un árbol grande para tomar fotos y un altar que, según entendí, se utilizaba para hacer misas secretas en tiempos de la guerra cristera.

No es un lugar muy grande, la experiencia se centra en pasear por el fondo de un cañón de unos 50m de alto

604071392.name: lugar familiar
604071392.author: a TripAdvisor user
604071392.reviewBody: Es un lugar al que se puede ir con la familia, se camina tranquilamente hasta llegar al fondo del ca\u00f1on que es como una b\u00f3veda.

653313798.name: Nice to learn some history of FRANCISCO Villa
653313798.author: a TripAdvisor user
653313798.reviewBody: We enjoyed the trip. The government needs to invest more money in making sure the museum is up to international standards.

itemReviewed.name: Historical Museum of the Mexican Revolution

address.streetAddress: Calle 10a. No. 3010

635465200.name: Don\'t miss this museum!
635465200.author: a TripAdvisor user
635465200.reviewBody: This was my favorite spot in Chihuahua. The museum is full of information about Mexico history and Pancho Villa\'s role. We spent hours there, reading every sign, and never tired of the information.

itemReviewed.name: Historical Museum of the Mexican Revolution

address.streetAddress: Calle 10a. No. 3010

632857979.name: excelent tourist guide
632857979.author: a TripAdvisor user
632857979.reviewBody: I visited this museum with my parents and we had a joyous experience, we were received by a tourist guide who offered his services only for tipping and he knew all the details of pancho villa\'s life. on top of that the museum is organized by the military and they offer a great service, always in time and very very cheap. If you\'re a student you\'ll get a discount, also seniors get a special rate. You can take photos in selected areas of the museum. I strongly advice to use the service of the tourist guide. At the end of the tour you can take a tram tour through the city.

itemReviewed.name: Historical Museum of the Mexican Revolution

address.streetAddress: Calle 10a. No. 3010

623903124.name: Lots to see
623903124.author: a TripAdvisor user
623903124.reviewBody: Very nice building and very interesting exhibits on the many dimensions of Pancho Villa\'s life.  You\'ll need about an hour.

itemReviewed.name: Historical Museum of the Mexican Revolution

address.streetAddress: Calle 10a. No. 3010

588665603.name: Interesting historical site and museum
588665603.author: a TripAdvisor user
588665603.reviewBody: This museum is located in the home of Pancho Villa. The rooms are furnished with original pieces. The exhibits are interesting and well presented. Highly recommended!

itemReviewed.name: Historical Museum of the Mexican Revolution

address.streetAddress: Calle 10a. No. 3010

572892074.name: Viva Mexico
572892074.author: a TripAdvisor user
572892074.reviewBody: This place is cool if your a mexico history fan there was a lot of neat old thing here. The quality of the exhibts about Pancho Villa is second to none. I would call it a must see.

itemReviewed.name: Historical Museum of the Mexican Revolution

address.streetAddress: Calle 10a. No. 3010

566958788.name: My great great grandmother came from Parral, Chihuahua
566958788.author: a TripAdvisor user
566958788.reviewBody:
then she took the whole family to Cd. Juarez up north, where I currently reside! Anyway, the military sergeant was very adamant about telling any visitor that no photography is allowed of any kind inside the museum, but it is ok outside on the grounds. Luv this place as any kind of Mexican history is my history. Alot of weapons and pictures of the Revolution. I wish they had more guards who I could ask questions. In a previous review, someone complained about the guard answering a question in Spanish, well Spanish is the national Language of my Mexico! Anyway, I wanted to ask some questions and no one was around. There were only about 3 soldiers in the whole place, and one was in charge in front. there are cameras all around, so please really do not take any photos. I have heard from my locals that if you defy the Mexican police or military, they can confiscate your camera or phone!

I also enjoyed looking at all of the old furniture in the whole house. Made me think of the time, my great grandma and all the lovely stuff she got to enjoy! I have been here before, but I will always return! The grounds and the museums are well kept by the military. IT was Dona Luz's wish to give her home to the military to preserve it as a museum for future generations. There is a tunnel that supposedly our hero Francisco Villa had constructed in order to escape. I do NOT believe any one was punished for his assassination!

This museum is a little far for the average American. I recommend taking a tour, a cab, or a bus. I walked back downtown. If you get hungry or thirsty, there is a restaurant and a little store at the corner to buy a drink!. THE cHEPE is close to here

itemReviewed.name: Historical Museum of the Mexican Revolution

address.streetAddress: Calle 10a. No. 3010

563956909.name: Pancho Villa lives!
563956909.author: a TripAdvisor user
563956909.reviewBody: At this amazingly maintained museum, you could imagine Pacho Villa being in one of the other many rooms in the place. The staff there is extremely helpful and knowledgeable. While we were there, one of the guards could not initially respond to a question my partner had, but tracked us down when he had the answer. A must visit when in the beautiful and friendly Mexican city of Chihuahua

itemReviewed.name: Historical Museum of the Mexican Revolution

address.streetAddress: Calle 10a. No. 3010

561339179.name: Highly recommended!
561339179.author: a TripAdvisor user
561339179.reviewBody: Highly recommended!  This museum is excellent.  It is administered by the Mexican Military, so the grounds and exhibits are impeccably maintained. 555977023.name: Pancho Villa Museum and his 25 Wives!
555977023.author: a TripAdvisor user
555977023.reviewBody:
The Historical Muesum of the Mexican Revolution is really by any other name in honor of Pancho Villa. 

Our Tour guide, organized by the Copper Canyon Adventure Tours, walked and gave us a first hand tour of what was Pancho Villa's former home, now a beautiful museum. 

Many well preserved artifacts, military as well as pictures and furniture of the Villa Home, carefully preserved by the first and only true wife, Luz Corral. When you visit, you will see what I mean about this particular fact. You can also see the full restored car in which Pancho Villa got assassinated. 

In  the main entrance, there is a photo of 25 women claiming to be "wives" of Sr. Villa (see photo). I say this not to diminish his greatness, but rather as a interesting fact of his life, especially as Sra. Villa appeared to weather Pancho's notoriety in extramarital affairs.  

General Villa is well recognized in military circle as being one of the last great Calvary Generals of 20th Century...out maneuvering our US General Pershing!

Great Museum...something to see and appreciate.

address.streetAddress: Calle 10a. No. 3010

456443944.name: Viva Villa
456443944.author: a TripAdvisor user
456443944.reviewBody:
Built on land purchased for business the home was built for his wife Señora doña Luz Corral and called "Quinta Luz".

It is dedicated to the life and death of Mexican Revolutionary, Francisco "Pancho" Villa.

Villa was taking a fairly standard visit to Parral, Mexico on July 20, 1923. However, he usually went accompanied by a number of bodyguards, and this time he went with only four associates. On his drive home, in a 1919 Dodge roadster that can be viewed in the Museum, someone shouted out "Viva Villa!" After that, seven riflemen appeared and fired more than forty bullets into the car. Nine bullets hit Villa; four went into his head. He died immediately. His body was found with his hand reaching for his gun.

Near the end of her life, Luz Corral received visitors from bed, too weak to rise. She died at age 89 on July 6, 1981. In 1981, when she became ill and too advanced in age to maintain the house, she made an offer that when she died the house would be donated to the city provided that they turned it into a museum in honor of Villa. The Ministry of Defense accepted the offer. Because of the poor state in which it was received many restorations had to be made by the National Institute of Anthropology and History.

The house re-opened on November 17, 1982 under the name of the name "Historical Museum of the Revolution". The office and music room are used to display the personal belongings of Villa. There are photographs and other personal belongings of Villa's era. One exhibit is the car he was traveling in with his escort on the day he was assassinated.

On the first floor of the museum are utensils and furniture that were commonly used by the Villa Corral family.

On the second floor are five showrooms and the Hall of Arms where weapons Francisco Villa used in many combat missions while part of the Northern Division. Some the weapons that are displayed are revolvers, rifles, machine guns, cavalry sabers, baskets and leather cases with brass. There is a photograph of Rafael Mendoza, a native of Maderas, Chihuahua, who during the Mexican Revolution invented the first machine gun air cooled 250 rounds per minute.

In one of the showcases known as the Tragic Room people are able to witness the death of General Villa. In the showcase there is a display that shows the map of the route Villa took before his assassination; also on display are photographs and his death mask, taken three hours after his death

Overall it was an excellent museum with much to see and learn about the history of Mexico.

itemReviewed.name: Historical Museum of the Mexican Revolution

address.streetAddress: Calle 10a. No. 3010

346555357.name: A lot of potential
346555357.author: a TripAdvisor user
346555357.reviewBody:
When you're talking about the history of Mexico and the Mexican Revolution, Pancho Villa looms as a major historical figure. He's an icon. You can readily find Pancho Villa t-shirts, magnets, postcards and the like for sale.

These buildings were one of his houses. The museum contains a lot of the artifacts from the period. When you come here, you can find the car he was shot in, the table where they signed the agreements at the Convention of Aguascalientes and his death mask. In addition, there are also beautiful murals and room after room of photos with captions in Spanish and poorly translated English.

This can all be seen for the nominal price of 10 pesos, a bargain. No guide available. No movie in English or Spanish. Nothing like that.

If you contrast this park with a park dedicated to a minor American founding father - say Friendship Hill in Pennsylvania for Albert Gallatin - you're going to be mystified as to why this place isn't made into a bigger deal than it is. Gallatin is nowhere as important to American history as Villa is to modern Mexican history. You come here, you get no clear picture of the events of the Mexican revolution. You get no clear sense of what made Pancho Villa the commander he was. No sense of the times. You can't buy books to read about the man or his time. It's like people get distracted by Villa's brash, extroverted personality and the big sombrero and don't see the political cunning and ruthlessness that made his men put trust in him to right the wrongs.

History is a collection of stories. This museum does a poor job of telling them.  Pancho Villa is about one of the most fascinating characters you can find. If I hadn't read Villa and Zapata: A History of the Mexican Revolution by Frank McLynn I would have no idea what was possible.

The museum is administered by the Mexican army and soldiers aren't curators. The only reason I gave this place 3/5 is that the artifacts are such a big deal. Please, people! Do more with this place! It's potentially a treasure! Hire a real curator who can relate the legacy of the revolution to others young and old, foreign and domestic!

address.streetAddress: Calle 10a. No. 3010

299021482.name: Casa de Pancho Villa
299021482.author: a TripAdvisor user
299021482.reviewBody:
This is the home of Francisco "Pancho" Villa and it is also the Museum of the Mexican Revolution. The tour allows you to see the living areas where Pancho and his first wife lived. Villa was quite the romantic and was married to 25 women at the same time. Upon his death, his home and its acres were awarded to his first wife, Doña Luz Corral, who was the only wife Villa married with a justice of the Peace. According to the Government, the other 24 women were just married with a priest and their marriages were not legally binding. 

The house was donated by Doña Luz Corral to the Mexican Department of Defense upon her death. The Defense Department turned it into a Museum about Pancho Villa and the Mexican Revolution. 

The front part of the house shows the living areas, bedrooms and bathrooms which Villa used during his life in Chihuahua. The back part of the house was used as sleeping quarters for Villa's officers. This back area now houses murals, photos, guns, artillery and artifacts from the Mexican Revolution. In the Courtyard area, is the Car in which Pancho Villa was shot and killed. There is also a nicely landscaped garden with posters, status and a canon.

The museum show a side to Pancho Villa that Americans seldom see. It shows him as the lovable Thief/Robin Hood figure which made him beloved by many northern Mexicans. While Governor of Chihuahua, Villa supported education by building schools and aiding the poor in need. As Leader of the Army of the North, he took land away from the Land Barons, such as the Creel-Terrazas family who were enriched under President Diaz. He and his army, returned much of the land back to poor and working class. 

Not without a downside, he also attacked Columbus, New Mexico, and started the Mexican/American War. Villa is a man of many sides and angles and a visit to his home will make him more real to you, your family and friends.

The Museum charges 10 pesos per person.

314846347.name: Best Mall in Chihuahua
314846347.author: a TripAdvisor user
314846347.reviewBody:
During our trip to Chihuahua we spent several afternoons here at the Mall. This is by far the best shopping mall in the Chihuahua and it is about the size of a mid-level American mall in the United States, like Sunland Park Mall in El Paso, TX or Aventura Mall in the Miami area. There are four anchor stores which include Liverpool, Sears, Ace Hardware and Sanborn's. The Liverpool store is very much like a Macy's or high end Dillard's in the United States. The Sears store here has a much greater selection of inventory than in the US and is paired with Pier One to provide a better selection. The Ace Hardware store is more of a furniture and home décor store than the local hardware stores here in states. Sanborn is a high end, Mexican chain store which is part department store, newsstand and high end electronics shop. Sanborn also hosts a sit down restaurant with a good buffet which is a good place to grab lunch or dinner. 

A true joy and great value is the Cinepolis Movie theatre on the second floor. The Cinepolis houses 12 screens, 8 regular and 4 VIP. If you join the Club Cinepolis at the theatre for free, it enables you to see first run movies quite affordably. With the card, you get 2 for one movies on Tuesdays. Matinees before 2:00pm are around $2 US.  If you have 4 people in your party, you can use to card to get everyone in for only 100 pesos or about 6 dollars and 70 cents before 2pm. Incredible right! For those taking your wife or date out, consider the VIP seating which provides complete dinner table service, including beer, wine and cocktails directly from your large comfortable lounge chairs while you watch the movie . The VIP Area cost around $7.50 per person and is a great splurge. The movies are all first runs either in English with Spanish subtitle or all dubbed into Spanish. 

There is a regular styled food court on the second floor opposite of the Cinepolis. Here you will find Mc Donald's, Burger King, Subway, Dominos and several Mexican and Asian fast food places. The Mexican People love their ice cream and frozen yogurt shops. The mall has no less than 5 of these shops selling ice cream by the cone or ounce. 

There are also several sit down restaurants on the first floor next to Ace Hardware. I greatly enjoyed the ComicX restaurant, which is a hamburger restaurant styled on the characters from Marvel and DC Comic books and is similar to Planet Hollywood. 
Please see my review. There is also a Chili's and Wing Stop for those wanting additional choices.

For those seeking to buy or upgrade their cell phones, the mall, by far, has the best options in Chihuahua with a huge Tel-cel store, Moviestar and several others companies to choice from. You can also book your next flight out at the Interjet ticket office. 

There are also many Hair and beauty salons, nail shops and dress stores to entertain the ladies in your group.

There is a children's play area at the end of mall for parents with children who get a little restless from shopping. There is also an arcade and Piccolo Mondo, which is childcare facility that will watch the kids while you shop for a fee. There is also Julio Cepeda, which is toy store, and pet store to entertain the kids too.

One really great find is the Gonwill bookstore on the second floor above the ComicX restaurant. Here you will find the best selections of books in English and Spanish for the whole family. It is very close to a Barnes and Nobles here in the States with similar pricing.

Please note that there is a 10 peso an hour fee for parking you car at the Fashion Mall which is payable at the kiosks near the main entrance. There is also bus service from the central/Downtown area of Chihuahua on the RC-02 Panamericana Mirador route which takes about 30 minutes to go to downtown. The bus costs 6 pesos one way and is the most cost effect way around town. There you can connect to the main North-South Vivabus line to key areas and hotels around the City. See route photos. There is also taxi stands which will run you about 45 to 120 pesos each way depending on how many sections you cross on the tariff map. I have include a couple photos of the taxi rate tariff map posted at the mall if it helps.  

If you are staying a one of the several Hotels next to the mall, Holiday Inn, Staybridge, Hampton Inn or Wingate, just walk over to the Mall which is less than a quarter mile.

Enjoy the shopping!

314839812.name: Learn about Art and the Building of the Mexican Railroad
314839812.author: a TripAdvisor user
314839812.reviewBody:
La Casa Redonda is a railroad museum and art gallery in the City of Chihuahua, Mexico. It is known to locals in English as the Round House or is Spanish Casa Redonda. The Museum has been made out of the old train engine repair facilities of the Central Mexican railroad. The function of the round houses were to provide locomotives minor repairs and maintenance, inspection, procurement, accommodation service. The Round Houses consisted of three key elements: a turntable, buildings and courtyards, annexes, which housed the services required for its operation. The turntable enabled one man to turn a heavy locomotive engine onto different tracks which would send it through routes in Mexico. 

Today, the La Casa Redonda serves as a locomotive museum which tells the story of Ferrocarriles Nacionales de Mexico railroads during the last hundred years. It also provides a wealth of train models and information which allows you and your children to understand how locomotives and railroads which used and maintained. 

A large part of the museum is also a wonderful art gallery which is currently hosting a grand exhibit of French Art and posters by Toulouse Lautrec and other Mexican and world artists. There are also art appreciation classes for adults and children held several times throughout the year. The "Nights at La Casa Redonda" series present musical concerts and exhibitions throughout the year as well. 

I found the 15 pesos entry fee, about a dollar US, a great value to see the many wonderful models, history and the original Toulouse Lautrec art. Make a definite plan to stop by if you are in the area and definitely if you are attending an expo at the Convention Center next door. 

La Casa Redonda is right next to the Center for Expositions and Conventions in the old railroad yards off Ave Tecnologico. 

The Museum is open from 10:00am to 7:00pm and entrance fees are 15 pesos for adults and 5 pesos for children and seniors.
